title: Harvey-Bradshaw Index (HBI) for Crohn's Disease
description: Stratifies severity of Crohn's disease using only clinical parameters. A simplified version of the Crohn's Disease Activity Index (CDAI) that correlates 93% with CDAI but doesn't require laboratory tests.

parameters.name: general_wellbeing
parameters.description: General well-being (assessed for the previous day)

parameters.name: abdominal_pain
parameters.description: Abdominal pain (assessed for the previous day)

parameters.name: liquid_stools
parameters.description: Number of liquid or soft stools per day (assessed for the previous day)

ranges.interpretation: Patient's Crohn's disease is in remission. The score indicates minimal or no disease activity. Continue current maintenance therapy and routine monitoring.
Patient has mild Crohn's disease activity. Consider optimization of current therapy or initiation of treatment if not already on therapy. Close monitoring is recommended.

Patient has moderate Crohn's disease activity. Treatment escalation is typically warranted. Consider systemic corticosteroids, immunomodulators, or biologic therapy depending on current treatment status.

Patient has severe Crohn's disease activity. Urgent treatment intensification is needed. Consider hospitalization, intravenous corticosteroids, and/or rapid initiation of biologic therapy. Evaluate for complications.

references: Harvey RF, Bradshaw JM. A simple index of Crohn's-disease activity. Lancet. 1980 Mar 8;1(8167):514. doi: 10.1016/s0140-6736(80)92767-1.

Peyrin-Biroulet L, Panés J, Sandborn WJ, Vermeire S, Danese S, Feagan BG, et al. Defining Disease Severity in Inflammatory Bowel Diseases: Current and Future Directions. Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol. 2016 Mar;14(3):348-354.e17. doi: 10.1016/j.cgh.2015.06.001.

Gomes P, du Boulay C, Smith CL, Holdstock G. Relationship between disease activity indices and colonoscopic findings in patients with colonic inflammatory bowel disease. Gut. 1986 Jan;27(1):92-5. doi: 10.1136/gut.27.1.92.
formula: HBI Score = General well-being (0-4) + Abdominal pain (0-3) + Number of liquid stools (1 point per stool) + Abdominal mass (0-3) + Complications (1 point each)
notes: The HBI has a 93% correlation with the CDAI but is much simpler to use
First three parameters (well-being, pain, stools) are assessed for the previous day
A reduction of 3 points is considered clinically significant response to treatment
Patients scoring ≤3 are very likely to be in remission according to CDAI
Does not require laboratory tests unlike CDAI
